caption: Excellent tour and great place to go for history of the city and not just Notre Dame. Self guided tour with plenty to keep you busy for a couple of hours if you want to read/see everything, , but also offering a relatively short experience if you're looking for a short respite from the city streets. Lots of interesting artifacts and facts about the Siene made this a great experience. Highly recommend.
The display of the ruins is alright and not something very fascinating. Although I liked the Mammoth tusks which were on display.

We visited this historic crypt as part of our Notre-Dame tour with our Paris a pass, which required advanced reservations. It is the largest crypt in Europe and includes archaeological discoveries made during excavations in the 60s and 70s.  This crypt offers a unique perspective on urban and architectural evolution in the île de la Cité, the historical heart of Paris. We spent a good hour or so inside the crypt, you could easily spend a couple of hours in here, there is plenty of history on display, a wonderful journey through time of a Paris, since the time it was once called Lutetia!

Wow. I'm a history buff, but I was blown away by the sheer amount of interesting stuff under the current Parisian streets. From before the Romans to modern day, the entire museum is fascinating and thought provoking. I found it very, very cool - you really feel the weight of human lives and their daily activities. It's not on the standard tourist radar, but it is most definitely worth a detour.

Right underneath the viewing platform at the front of Notre Dame Cathedral.  A very well done display of the Roman ruins found while digging I. The area.  Was just €9 a person.  Nice displays in multiple languages.

There are surprisingly few ancient archaeological sites to visit in Paris, which makes this museum a rare and interesting place to visit. Most of the ruins are from the later years of Roman Lutetia, when the Île de la Cité was notably smaller than today, and include the remains of the old quayside and the late Roman bathhouse. However, there are also medieval cellars from subsequent houses, and displays on the importance of the Seine to the city’s growth and development. It’s not a big museum, and an hour or so is sufficient to see it, but worth visiting for anyone with even a passing interest in ancient Paris.

Nicely presented roman site.  Wasn't busy when we visited and bought tickets at the desk.  Stayed around an hour which made the visit good value for money although a little more information on the romans would have been nice, but enough information to describe the site.   There's also some information about Notre Dame and also the Hunchback of Notre Dame book.
It was a really cool place and luckily I got free access as an 18 year old.

Visiting the Crypte Archéologique du Parvis Notre-Dame was breathtaking. I stumbled upon on it during my morning run and had to capture the moment. It’s a marvel to see in person so definitely stop by the next time you’re in Paris.

Loved it!  There's so much human history here at Notre Dame, it's quite amazing this little island has withstood so much for so long.  The foundations, the coins, the review of the rebuilds and build-overs, and the detailed explanations of it all add to a wonderful visit to the cathedral above ground!
Very surprised by this visit. All explanatory panels are accessible and very complete Unexpectedly, there are so many ancient ruins at the foot of the church

Very interesting. Information plaques are in French and English only. The trip focused on Notre Dame the book, but I would have liked more information about the ruins. €9 entry fee. Amazing photos from 1850's
Impressive to see those ancient walls buried behind the floor, found during the excavation of the river and construction of Notre Dame and other structures. Recommended to see !

If you enjoy old roman vestige, this visit is for you. The ruins left correspond to Lutetia (former name of Paris) as it was on the island of la Cité, around the years 200 AC. The visit host a number of vidoes that reconstituted the life style and living condition of the Romans during their occupation of that part of the world. There is also quite some information on Notre Dame cathedral and the book the Hunch back of Notre Dame by Victor Hugo. Visit takes about 1 hour. Price Euro 9. Totally worth it.
Very small, no bathrooms, and an extra charge to see the 3D version of Notre Dame. But the displays were interesting and I liked the old river bank!

The Archaeological Crypt of the Parvis Notre-Dame (Crypte Archeologique) is located on the main square in front of Notre Dame and provides visitors a rare glimpse into Paris’ distant past. The site, discovered during excavations between 1965 and 1972, features ruins of the Gallo-Roman town called Lutetia, which rest beneath the surface of the Notre Dame Square. Entrance is €6 per adult and the attraction is included as part of the Paris Museum Pass.  Some consider this one of the most important archaeological sites in France, if not all of Europe, due to the relatively well-preserved building foundations, walls and other vestiges of the Gallo-Roman town of Lutetia, the precursor to Paris. Evidence of later structures from the middle ages, all the way to the 19th century is found at the site. In all, this 2200 square meters of various homes, bathhouses, shops, seawall and other ruins to be seen at the crypt.  In addition to the actual ruins, they make good use of interactive technology, providing visual displays of what the ancient city would have looked like. Further computer simulations provide glimpses into Notre Dame itself during various phases of its construction during the 12th to 14th centuries.  Overall, we very much enjoyed the Archaeological Crypt, finding this attraction well worth 30-45 minutes of your time before or after visiting Notre Dame Cathedral. Those with a interest in ancient history or ruins, will want to add this attraction to their list of must-see places to visit when in Paris.  Hint: The entrance to the crypt is found at the front of the main square, while facing the cathedral. Just look for the signs and the underground entrance.
Great place to visit if the weather is bad, as its indoors and underground. Sadly the notre Dame isn't open, but you can get some of the story of how the notrr5dame came to be while here

This was a very nice and interesting diversion during our recent trip to Paris. My wife and I actually didn't know that it existed, but we saw it when we visited Notre Dame, decided to go in, and paid for our tickets at the front.  I came out knowing much more about the history of the area and the architecture than I did before, so that is a "win" in my book. It may take you about an hour or so to move through, but it's definitely worth the money.  I should also mention that the staff were literal Heroes that day. When we went to a cafe shortly after visiting there, my wife discovered that her purse was missing from her backpack. At that point, if it hadn't been pickpocketed (would NOT have been an easy feat), there were only 2 places where it could possibly have been. It wasn't at the first (down at a spot on the Seine), so we went back to the Crypt, with our fingers and toes crossed. It turns out that she had left the purse at the ticket counter. The staff found it and kept it safe. One of the gentlemen working there even tried to seek us both out on social media to tell us, but neither of us use social media. But, we got it back safe and sound, which was a massive relief. It wouldn't have been the end of the world if it was gone; luckily her passport was not in there. However, it still would have been a MAJOR headache to get a new driver's license and cancel credit cards, not to mention the loss of a NOT insignificant amount of Euros. So again, from the bottoms of our hearts, THANK YOU!!!!!

Located beneath the foundations of Notre Dame, this ancient crypt is fabulous for learning about, and seeing relics of, the history of Paris. Signage and educational displays are in multiple languages, and are very good translations. There's a heavy dose of the history of coins found at the site, but plenty of othelr fascinating information and artifacts as well.  Skip the audio tour...The signage is that good!
Nice substitute for the Notre Dame cathedral. Tickets are timed and although there are not too may people it is smart to buy them ahead.
Interesting history of the foundation of Paris (Lutece) since antiquity as well as the history of Notre Dame and its renovation as inspired by Victor Hugo.
Currently can't go into the Notre Dame Cathedral, so this was as close as we could get. You end up learning a few things about how it was revived through story. Great for history buffs.

Pretty cool archeological crypt below the Notre Dame. Some interesting and mind boggling remains to see. Most of the poeple visiting Notre Dame do visit this crypt as well. Will reccommend only to the ones interested in dug up artifacts!
Archeological findings below the Notre Dame Cathedral are displayed in this museum. They correspond to around the 4th century CE till the last centuries. Ticket is free for kids.
Amazing insite into the history of the location with computerised interactive exhibitions and a spacious walk around the crypt ruins. It was free entry on the day we went so a nice bonus.

Our guide, Raphael was EXCELLENT! This was the best of our excursions here in Paris! If you are lucky enough to have Raphael as your guide you will learn a lot. He is extremely knowledgeable and personable with a great sense of humor, interacting with every person in our group, answering all our questions. He knows his history. This tour will not disappoint! I would give him more than 5 stars if possible! I recommend this  tour with Raphael immensely!
If you’re at the Notre Dame pay this a visit! It’s economical and great to see more of the local history through the ages.

My first visit here was surprising. There is a whole layer of Parisian history hidden under the surface.  For history buffs, this is a must see stop while in Paris.  The entrance is right next to the entrance to Cathedral de Notre-Dame, and while it's not a huge stop, it's well worth 30 - 60 minutes of your time to see how Paris evolved from this little island beginning.  Much of the ruins are still partially in tact and technology helps you visualize the rest.
Part of Museum pass. It is not particularly big but a nice change from paintings and sculptures. Has some interesting panels on how the city grew. There is a lot of focus on the coins used.

Probably only worth the visit if you already have the Paris Pass/Paris Museum Pass. While interesting with extensive history, there isn't much to see. It is clearly more geared toward children. Worth the stop if you've prepaid.

The underground museum contains ancient stone foundations from walls and docks left over from when Romans ruled the city. The place, in Notre Dame's shadow, also has an extensive collection of materials on cathedral’s rise, decay, and restoration. An under-appreciated gem.

How did I not know about this place?! I thought I was walking into the crypt for the Notre Dame church, but was pleasantly surprised when I found it was the archaelogical discovery of the remnants of medieval Paris.  My only dissapointment was there was not a book for purchase in English for me to digest later!
Wouldn't say it's worth it. Very small, not much to see, these pictures is 90% of what you can see here
It truly amazing place to see first hand the cultural heritage of Old Paris! You can even take a VR tour inside Notre Dame! Great for kids!
History buffs will love this step back in time. History of Paris and the Ile as well as of Notre Dame. Very interesting.
Very interesting excavation site.  I didn't know Paris was called Lutetia in Early Roman times.
Definitely worth the visit. A very interesting museum with informative explanations.
Absolutely love the history here. Nice... Very nice...
